resources.string: Effectively Learning Data Structures And Algorithms
Which of these is the core building block of data structures and algorithms problems?
Graphs
Patterns
Code
Trees
True or false: The most effective way to be prepared for data structures and algorithms interview problems is to memorize the code of each problem\'s solution line by line.
Why should you comment your solutions to data structures and algorithms problems?
To explain what every line of code does
Because comments make good code
It makes the code faster
To capture the core insight behind the problem and the high level approach
True or false: When you are completely stuck, you should just look at the entire solution in order to learn it.
Why is it healthy to struggle on data structures and algorithms problems?
That\'s just how data structures and algorithms are
You can tell your interviewer about it so they go easier on you
Because that\'s when your mind is able to do true learning
So you can complain about it on LinkedIn
Having The Proper Mindset
True or false: You need to care a lot about your Big Tech interview, because passing it will drastically improve your life. The more prominent it is in your brain, the more likely you are to pass.
How should you view interviews?
Make or break opportunities
Lottery tickets to make a lot more money
Opportunities to hang out with some talented tech people
Big tests, similar to final exams in school
True or false: Your input is much more important than the output and results you achieve.
Why should you not view interviews as a test?
Because they aren\'t
To reduce your anxiety and care less about the result
So they don\'t remind you of school
It takes too much mental capacity
True or false: You shouldn\'t take any breaks when studying for interviews, because the relentless focus will help you learn the material better.
Mentally Preparing For Interviews With Data Structures And Algorithms
True or false: Interviewing is all about how much you know. As long as you study a lot and understand enough material, you will pass the interview.
For almost everyone, what does the learning curve look like for data structures and algorithms?
Linear
Logarithmic
Quadratic
Exponential
True or false: It\'s completely normal and even a good sign when you feel dumb while studying data structures and algorithms.
What\'s the most important piece when you\'re learning data structures and algorithms material?
How many GitHub green boxes you can get
The quality of your learning system
How often you post to LinkedIn about your progress
The specs of your computer as many problems require a lot of compute and RAM

True or false: If you aren\'t making progress on data structures and algorithms after 2 months, your mind probably just isn\'t geared to understand them. At that point, you should be practical and just look for interviews that don\'t have these kinds of problems.
Truly Mastering A Data Structures And Algorithms Problem - 2 Sum Example
It\'s written in Python, which isn\'t a good interviewing language.
The space usage isn\'t optimal
It\'s inefficient; humans don\'t naturally think in terms of code
The solution is incomplete
Why is [Look for the difference and use a HashSet] a great way to remember the solution to 2 Sum?
It is compact
It trains your brain to convert high-level ideas into implementation
It captures the core of the problem
All of the above
What more general higher-level learning principles is also exercised alongside the proper mastery of data structures and algorithms problems?
Memorization
Thinking in terms of abstractions
Perseverance
Repetition
How Big Tech Judges Interview Performance Differently
What is the main extra axis that Big Tech companies will grade interview candidates on?
Space complexity
Cleanliness of the code
Communication skills
Programming language choice
As long as you get a correct, optimal solution, that is enough to pass a Big Tech interview round.
Why is communication so important in Big Tech companies?
There are a lot more stakeholders on every project, making the relevant audience at every point quite large
Their internal architecture is very custom, making your ability to learn new things much more important
Software engineers there are expected to be much more well-rounded and not just coding all the time
All of the above
True or false: Big Tech companies don\'t really care about what specific technologies and programming languages you have worked with.
What\'s the core high-level asset Big Tech interviewers look for?
Years of experience
Open-source contributions
Fundamentals
Usage of modern programming languages and frameworks
Inventing The API And Analyzing Your Solution
True or false: You should tackle the easiest, most trivial parts of a data structures and algorithms problem first, just to get it out of the way and boost your confidence.
What does it mean to [Invent the API]?
Describing what AWS server you would host your solution on
Talking about the REST interface your endpoint will have
Figuring out the run-time and space complexity of your code
Creating a method that you assume accomplishes some very straightforward piece of logic you need
True or false: A lot of the time, the interviewer won\'t care if you don\'t code out every single piece of the entire solution.
Why shouldn\'t you prioritize writing the simple utility methods your overall solution needs?
To save time
The interviewer doesn\'t get much signal watching you code these
So you can tackle the essence of the problem first instead
All of the above

True or false: If you are 100% confident that your solution doesn\'t have bugs, just tell your interviewer you are done and kick the conversation back to them to save time and move on to the next problem.
